item.title: Manias, Panics, and AI
item.description: By any metric, the US – and, by implication, the world – are now in the midst of an intense AI speculative boom. To assess whether all the investment pouring into the industry will build something useful, three questions must be addressed.

item.title: Will China Forcibly Boost Fertility?
item.description: China is widely expected to adopt a range of pronatalist policies in a bid to raise birth rates. But recent efforts to encourage women to have more babies will have short-lived effects, while coercive measures – such as bans on contraception and abortion – would trigger a public backlash and prove futile at best.

item.title: Why Do US Congressional Leaders Keep Beating the Stock Market?
item.description: Members of Congress continue to trade individual stocks even as they shape legislative agendas and gain access to non-public information. New research sheds light on how political power affects financial outcomes and underscores the need for reforms that draw a firm line between public office and private profit.

item.title: The Massive Costs of Anti-Immigration Policies
item.description: Even as aging populations leave the workforce and critical sectors scramble for talent, an anti-immigrant backlash is gathering force across much of the developed world. The result is a widening gap between economic fundamentals and policy choices that threatens long-term growth and prosperity.

item.title: Building Global Africa
item.description: If the global community of people of African descent was fashioned into an integrated economy, it would present an unparalleled opportunity for deepening trade, mobilizing investment, and creating shared prosperity. All that has been lacking is a vision, and the political will to pursue it.

item.title: Three Cheers for the London Consensus
item.description: While the old Washington Consensus forced developing countries into an austerity straitjacket that inflicted enormous pain on ordinary people, a new set of principles from a multinational roster of economists organized by the London School of Economics offers a long-needed alternative. This time, politics isn't assumed away.

item.title: Renminbi Internationalization Is Closing the Climate Finance Gap
item.description: Through a trifecta of fast-growing markets for renminbi-denominated bonds, China is showing that it can support domestic sustainability projects across the Global South. With the United States and other traditional creditors stepping back, Chinese finance is filling the vacuum.

item.title: A Just Transition for Land
item.description: Annual economic losses linked to desertification, land degradation, and drought amount to $878 billion – far more than the investments needed to mitigate their impact. Only by using innovative financing mechanisms and collaborating more effectively can a just transition to a sustainable and resilient land economy be achieved.

item.title: Creative Destruction Should Not Spare Commercial Banks
item.description: New technologies offer new opportunities to revamp payment and credit systems, making them not only more efficient but also safer. It would be a shame if these were foregone because banks believe that they have a right to a business model that they inherited from political compromises struck centuries ago.

item.title: Can America Win the New Race for Scientific Leadership?
item.description: Even as China and the United States compete for scientific leadership, the Trump administration has slashed investment in research and tightened immigration rules. If the US has truly entered a second Cold War, it should repeat the strategy that helped it win the first one: expanding the scientific frontier at home.

item.title: Deeper into the Public Procurement Goldmine
item.description: Public procurement is one of the world’s most powerful yet underused industrial-policy tools. Rather than treating procurement as a routine administrative task, policymakers must harness it to guide innovators toward developing and scaling solutions to complex societal challenges, from infrastructure to climate resilience.

item.title: The G20 Must Follow Through on Debt Relief
item.description: Governments across Africa, Asia, and Latin America have been forced to cut spending on education, health care, and infrastructure to keep funds flowing to foreign creditors, undermining global stability and prosperity. To break this vicious cycle, G20 leaders must urgently revamp the Common Framework for Debt Treatment.

item.title: Nigeria Needs Safe Schools
item.description: Terrorists are once again targeting Nigeria’s schools, kidnapping more than 300 children in recent weeks. The international community must provide the Nigerian government with immediate surveillance support to secure the release of the abducted students, as well as long-term resources to help make the country’s schools safer.

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Are Hitting India Hard
item.description: Donald Trump’s punishing tariffs have laid bare the fragility of India’s export model, which depends on a handful of markets and a narrow band of relatively low-value-added products. Only by embracing a new model – which emphasizes diversification, regional cooperation, and value addition – can India build long-term resilience.

item.title: The Future of China’s “Electro-State”
item.description: China has built the machinery of an innovative, low-carbon industrial economy capable of leading the global net-zero transition and the unfolding AI revolution. But whether this model will be sustainable depends on China's ability to overcome several major challenges.

item.title: MAGA’s Death Wish
item.description: The future Donald Trump's supporters want – a pre-feminist white Christian America – cannot be attained, which means that his Make America Great Again movement has no constructive program. It can only destroy, because nothing it can build would satisfy it.

item.title: The Judge at the End of Europe
item.description: When, in a few years’ time, almost everyone is claiming that they opposed Israel’s war crimes in Gaza, the world will remember Judge Nicolas Guillou of the International Criminal Court fondly. But the world will also remember how Europe’s leaders collaborated with Donald Trump by enforcing baseless US sanctions against Guillou.

item.title: The Triple-Return Ocean Economy
item.description: In the face of escalating climate, geopolitical, and financial instability, investors are underestimating an asset offering outsize environmental, social, and financial returns. But taking advantage of the opportunities provided by the blue economy requires building the foundational architecture for ocean finance.

item.title: Get Ready for an Overdue Fed Overhaul
item.description: US Federal Reserve officials would rather “stick to their knitting” than confront the complex forces that are reshaping the economy. Unless the next Fed chair shakes the institution out of its complacency, continued policy-induced volatility and intensifying political attacks are all but guaranteed.

item.title: Make Russia Pay for Its War on Ukraine
item.description: As many European leaders acknowledge, the United States has left Europe (including the United Kingdom and Norway) with no choice but to see to its own defense. Using frozen Russian assets to provide a Reparations Loan to Ukraine is a forceful step in this direction that Europeans could take without US involvement.
